    • Introducing mRNA bias into simulations with scaling factors

    Introducing mRNA bias into simulations with scaling factors

    Alexander Dietrich

    11/29/2021

    simulator_scaling_factors.Rmd

    Using scaling factors

    This package allows the user to introduce an mRNA bias into pseudo-bulk RNA-seq samples. Different cell-types contain different amounts of mRNA (Dendritic cells for examples contain much more than Neutrophils); this bias can be added into simulations artificially in different ways.
    The scaling factors will always be applied on the single-cell dataset first, altering its expression profiles accordingly, and then the pseudo-bulk samples are generated with an aggregation method (mean by default). By default we multiply the scaling factor with the dataset, but you can change this to division in the scaling_factor_aggregation parameter of simulate_bulk().

    Pre-defined scaling factors

    Some studies have proposed scaling factors for immune cells, such as EPIC (Racle et al. 2017) or quantiseq (Finotello et al. 2019), deconvolution tools which correct for the mRNA bias internally using these values:

    epic <- data.frame(
  type = c("B cells", 
           "Macrophages",
           "Monocytes", 
           "Neutrophils",
           "NK cells",
           "T cells",
           "T cells CD4",
           "T cells CD8",
           "T helper cells",
           "T regulatory cells",
           "otherCells",
           "default"),
  mRNA = c(0.4016,
           1.4196,
           1.4196,
           0.1300,
           0.4396,
           0.3952,
           0.3952,
           0.3952,
           0.3952,
           0.3952,
           0.4000,
           0.4000)
  
)

epic
#>                  type   mRNA
#> 1             B cells 0.4016
#> 2         Macrophages 1.4196
#> 3           Monocytes 1.4196
#> 4         Neutrophils 0.1300
#> 5            NK cells 0.4396
#> 6             T cells 0.3952
#> 7         T cells CD4 0.3952
#> 8         T cells CD8 0.3952
#> 9      T helper cells 0.3952
#> 10 T regulatory cells 0.3952
#> 11         otherCells 0.4000
#> 12            default 0.4000
    quantiseq <- data.frame(
  type = c("B cells",
           "Macrophages",
           "MacrophagesM2",
           "Monocytes",
           "Neutrophils",
           "NK cells",
           "T cells CD4",
           "T cells CD8",
           "T regulatory cells",
           "Dendritic cells",
           "T cells"),
  mRNA = c( 65.66148,
            138.11520,
            119.35447,
            130.65455,
            27.73634,
            117.71584,
            63.87200,
            70.25659,
            72.55110,
            140.76091,
            68.89323)
  
)

quantiseq
#>                  type      mRNA
#> 1             B cells  65.66148
#> 2         Macrophages 138.11520
#> 3       MacrophagesM2 119.35447
#> 4           Monocytes 130.65455
#> 5         Neutrophils  27.73634
#> 6            NK cells 117.71584
#> 7         T cells CD4  63.87200
#> 8         T cells CD8  70.25659
#> 9  T regulatory cells  72.55110
#> 10    Dendritic cells 140.76091
#> 11            T cells  68.89323

    When you want to apply one of these scaling factors into your simulation (therefore in-/decreasing the expression signals for the cell-types), use the custom value for the scaling_factor parameter. Note, that the input for custom_scaling_vector needs to be a named list, so we need to transform the dataframes from above slightly:

    scaling_epic <- epic$mRNA
names(scaling_epic) <- epic$type
sim_epic <- simulate_bulk(data=dataset,
                          scenario = "random",
                          scaling_factor="custom", 
                          custom_scaling_vector = scaling_epic, 
                          nsamples = 100, 
                          ncells=1000,
                          ncores=4)

    With this approach, we can also try out some custom scaling factors, for example increasing the expression levels for a single cell-type (B cells) by 10-fold compared to the rest. All cell-types which are not mentioned in the named list given to custom_scaling_vector will be transformed with a scaling factor of 1, meaning nothing changes for them.

    sim_extreme_b <- simulate_bulk(data = dataset, 
                               scenario = "random",
                               scaling_factor = "custom",
                               custom_scaling_vector = c("B cells"=10), 
                               nsamples = 100, 
                               ncells = 1000, 
                               ncores = 4)

    Important: Take care, that the cell-type annotation names in your dataset are the same as in the scaling factor! Otherwise the scaling factor will not be applied or even worse, applied to a different cell-type.

    Dataset specific scaling factors

    You can also choose to calculate scaling factors, which are depending on your provided single-cell dataset. Compared to the previous section, this will give a unique value for each cell rather than a cell-type, making it possibly more sensitive.

    Reads and genes

    Two straight forward approaches would be the number of reads or number of expressed genes/features. For this, we need to generate our initial dataset object a little bit differently and add more information to the internal annotation table:

      ds <- dataset(annotation = annotation,
                count_matrix = count_matrix,
                name = "reads_and_genes",
                read_number_col = "total_reads",      # add read number column
                additional_cols = c("gene_number"))   # add gene number column

    Here our annotation dataframe contains additional columns such as total_reads and gene_number. The first gives the number of reads per cell, the other the number of expressed genes per cell. The number of reads will be stored in the dataset annotation in the read_number column, all columns we add via the additional_cols parameter will keep their original name. We can now use these values for mRNA bias introduction based on reads or genes:

    
sim_reads <- simulate_bulk(data=ds, 
                           scenario = "random", 
                           scaling_factor="read-number",  # use number of reads as scaling factor
                           nsamples = 100, 
                           ncells=1000, 
                           ncores=4)

sim_genes <- simulate_bulk(data = ds,
                           scenario = "random",
                           scaling_factor = "gene_number", # use gene_number column as scaling factor
                           nsamples = 100,
                           ncells = 1000,
                           ncores = 4)

    These options would also allow you to use other numerical measurements you have for the single cells as scaling factors, such as weight or size for example.

    Spike-ins

    One other numerical measurement can be spike-ins. Usually the number of reads mapped to spike-in molecules per cell is given in the cell annotations. If this is the case, they can be stored in the dataset annotation using the spike_in_col parameter, where you indicate the name of the column from the annotation dataframe in which the spike-in information is stored. To calculate a scaling factor from this, the number of reads are also necessary, so we will add this information as well (as above using the read_number_col parameter).

      ds <- dataset(annotation = annotation,
                count_matrix = count_matrix,
                name = "spike-ins",
                spike_in_col = "ercc_sum",   # add spike-in column
                read_number_col = "total_reads")

    The scaling factor with spike-ins is calculated as the “% of reads NOT mapped to spike-in reads,” or: (n_reads - n_spike_in)/n_reads for each cell. We apply it like this:

    sim_spike <- simulate_bulk(data = ds,
                           scenario = "random",
                           scaling_factor = "spike-in", # use spike-in scaling factor
                           nsamples = 100,
                           ncells = 1000,
                           ncores = 4)

    Census - estimate mRNA counts per cell

    Census is an approach which tries to convert TPM counts into relative transcript counts. This basically means, you get the mRNA counts per cell, which can differ between cell-types.
    (Qiu et al. 2017) state in their paper, that it should only be applied to TPM/FPKM normalized data, but I tried it out with raw expression counts as well, which worked as well.
    Census calculates a vector with a scaling value for each cell in a sample. You can switch this feature on, by setting the scaling_factor parameter to census.

    sim_census <-  simulate_bulk(data = dataset_file,
                             scenario = "spike-in", 
                             scaling_factor = "census",   # use census scaling factor
                             nsamples = 100, 
                             ncells=1000, 
                             ncores = 4)

    In our analysis we found, that Census is basically a complicated way of estimating the number of expressed genes per cell. It will remain to the user to decide if he/she wants to use census or simply the number of expressed genes (as shown above) as scaling factor.

    References

    Finotello, Francesca, Clemens Mayer, Christina Plattner, Gerhard Laschober, Dietmar Rieder, Hubert Hackl, Anne Krogsdam, et al. 2019. “Molecular and Pharmacological Modulators of the Tumor Immune Contexture Revealed by Deconvolution of RNA-Seq Data.” Genome Medicine 11 (1): 34. https://doi.org/10.1186/s13073-019-0638-6.
    Qiu, Xiaojie, Andrew Hill, Jonathan Packer, Dejun Lin, Yi-An Ma, and Cole Trapnell. 2017. “Single-Cell mRNA Quantification and Differential Analysis with Census.” Nature Methods 14 (3): 309–15. https://doi.org/10.1038/nmeth.4150.
    Racle, Julien, Kaat de Jonge, Petra Baumgaertner, Daniel E. Speiser, and David Gfeller. 2017. “Simultaneous Enumeration of Cancer and Immune Cell Types from Bulk Tumor Gene Expression Data.” eLife 6 (November): e26476. https://doi.org/10.7554/eLife.26476.
